div.p: To the northeast of the route taken by the Corps of Discovery lived the many communities making up the Ojibwe or anishinaabepeople (Chippewa is a name not preferred by most anishinaabe today but it is part of the official designation of a number of their current reservations). Pushed westward by conflicts with Iroquoian peoples, the anishinaabein the early nineteenth century occupied a vast region, from the shores of Lake Huron and Lake Superior westward to the Turtle Mountains of present day North Dakota. Much of the homeland of the anishinaabewas heavily wooded with a great deal of surface water—quite different from the environments of many of the Native peoples encountered by the Corps of Discovery. Dwelling in bark-covered domed lodges, they fished, harvested wild rice, hunted and trapped a variety of small game animals, and made sugar from tapping maple trees. In the decades following the Corps of Discovery, the leadership of such individuals as Flatmouth (pictured here), from the Leech Lake Reservation, helped the anishinaabefor the most part to coexist peacefully with the United States government. The anishinaabewere placed on reservations scattered across North Dakota, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan and reserves in Canada. Today many of these various reservation communities, although struggling economically, are actively involved in writing their own histories, protecting treaty rights, and preserving and teaching their traditional language and culture.
